title: 114_hr470
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest Land Adjustment Act of 2015". It includes findings and definitions. The "Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest Land Adjustment Act of 2015" includes findings by Congress that certain National Forest System land in Georgia is inefficient to manage or has lost its value for National Forest purposes. The Act authorizes the disposal of this land for the public interest, with proceeds used by the Forest Service to purchase land for National Forest purposes in Georgia. The term "Secretary" in the Act refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The Act also grants land conveyance authority. The Secretary is authorized to sell or exchange United States' rights in National Forest System land in Georgia totaling 3,841 acres. The Secretary is authorized to sell or exchange 30 tracts of land totaling approximately 3,841 acres in Georgia, as depicted on maps dated September 24, 2013. The maps will be available for public inspection until the land is sold or exchanged, and the Secretary may modify boundaries. The Secretary will convey land sold under this Act by quitclaim deed and may reserve any rights-of- The Secretary may modify boundaries based on land management considerations and convey land by quitclaim deed. The Secretary can reserve rights-of-way or other interests in land sold under this Act for management purposes or to protect the public interest. The Secretary may reserve rights-of-way or other interests in land sold under this Act for management purposes or to protect the public interest. Land cannot be sold for less than market value, determined by appraisal or competitive bid, following specific appraisal standards. The Act allows the Secretary to reserve rights-of-way or interests in land for management purposes. Land must be sold at market value determined by appraisal or competitive bid. Appraisal must adhere to specific standards and approval by the Secretary is required. Consideration for land sale or exchange must be paid in cash. The Secretary may sell land at public or private sale, with consideration for sale or exchange to be paid in cash. The Secretary can accept a cash equalization payment exceeding 25% of the land value in an exchange. The Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 allows the Secretary to accept a cash equalization payment exceeding 25% of the land value in an exchange. The Secretary may sell land through public or private sale, including competitive auctions or bids, based on what is in the best interest of the United States. The Secretary can also make solicitations for the sale of land. The Secretary, under the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, can sell land through public or private sale, including auctions, and may use brokers for the sale. The Secretary can also make solicitations for land sales and reject inadequate offers. The Secretary can use brokers to sell land authorized by the Act and pay commissions from the sale proceeds. The Secretary has the authority to reject offers deemed inadequate or not in the public interest. The Secretary can deposit sale proceeds in the Sisk Act fund for land acquisition in Georgia without further appropriation. Funds cannot be used to acquire land without owner consent.
